PageElement.TextBox:
This lesson will teach you about  environmental offences, and enforcement and prosecution mechanisms employed by the RMA when an activity is found to be in breach of the RMA.
 
You should complete the lesson in about 15 minutes.
 
At the end of the lesson you should have a clear understanding of the four principal enforcement mechanisms under the RMA:
 
  • infringement notices
 
  • abatement notices
 
  • enforcement orders
 
  • prosecutions.
 
In addition you should understand who can be liable for environmental offences, the basic defences that are available and what to do to minimise the risk of committing an offence.
 
To get started, please click on the ► button below.

CF Ltd buys an industrial plant in a mixed use zone (i.e. where there are both residential and industrial activities). Unknown to CFL, the site is contaminated by the operations of the previous owner who had been storing toxic waste on the site. The council becomes aware of the problem via a neighbour, Mrs Brown, who is concerned about possible discharges on to her land.
 
Consider this scenario while reading the next pages...

This lesson sets out some of the legal consequences of committing an environmental offence. An environmental offence is any action (or failure to take action) which breaches the RMA.

Examples of environmental offences include:
 
  • offences relating to some type of unlawful discharge, such as land, water or air discharge and waste disposal offences
 
  • clearing native vegetation and habitats, or damaging heritage/archaeological sites
 
  • failing to comply with the conditions of a resource consent.
 
There are various tools in the RMA which the council can use if it suspects that an environmental offence has been committed:
 
  • infringement notices
  • abatement notices
  • enforcement orders
  • prosecutions.
 
Each of these is considered in turn.

Infringement notices involve instant fines for low level offences under the RMA. The process for issuing an infringement notice is very similar to other types of infringement notices, for example, parking tickets.
 
Infringement notices are a relatively new power available to councils and it is likely that over time councils will use them more frequently. This is because (similar to parking tickets) it involves less work/cost for councils to enforce compliance with council rules.
 
Council officers can issue infringement notices on the spot in cases where they have observed an offence or have reasonable grounds to believe an offence has been committed.
 
Although infringement notices are relatively modest, care should be taken when deciding whether they should be challenged - failure to do so will be seen as an acceptance of guilt. If the infringement notice arose out of a one-off event which will not occur again, then this approach may be appropriate.  However, if it relates to an event which could happen again, careful consideration should be given to defending the matter.

Abatement notices can be issued by either a regional or district council. They can either require a person or company to cease an activity, or to take steps to avoid, remedy or mitigate adverse effects on the environment.
 
An abatement notice can be issued against either the person causing the problem or the owner/occupier of the land concerned, or both.
 
The enforcement officer issuing the abatement notice must have 'reasonable cause' for doing so. The only challenge to his/her decision to issue a notice is by way of appeal to the Environment Court.

Until the RMA was amended in 1997, appealing an abatement notice automatically meant an abatement notice was stayed (i.e. the alleged offender did not have to comply with the notice) until the appeal was dealt with. The position now is the opposite – the abatement notice must be complied with even if an appeal is lodged, although the Environment Court can be asked to stay the notice, provided the appeal is lodged within 15 working days of receiving the abatement notice.
 
The Court will then balance the adverse effects on the environment, if the stay is not granted, against the effects on the person or company served with the notice. There is, however, a ‘golden rule’ to consider when contemplating appeals.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for the ‘golden rule’ regarding appeals
    The golden rule is – if an abatement notice is served, make sure the question of appeal is dealt with immediately. If you are confident you can comply with the abatement notice or, by dealing with the council directly, you can resolve matters and get the notice withdrawn, there may be no need to appeal. However, after 15 working days have expired, it is too late to appeal.
     
    Care should therefore be taken when foregoing an appeal, even if the appeal would only be a ‘stop gap’ until the matter is resolved.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox: The abatement notice will not always require work to be stopped, and will usually give time to comply. Failing to comply with an abatement notice is an offence under the RMA and may result in prosecution action (dealt with in this lesson).

For more complicated matters, or if there is some uncertainty about issuing an abatement notice, councils may apply to the Environment Court for an enforcement order.
 
Individuals/companies may apply for enforcement orders, especially where they cannot get the council to take action, or where they have some motive to stop the activity. An enforcement order can be applied for against the person who caused the problem (e.g. previous landowner) or the current land owner/occupier or against both.
 
Enforcement orders can cover a wide range of matters, but for the most part they are used like injunctions. The Environment Court can issue interim enforcement orders to get a matter before the Court quickly. An enforcement order is an order of the Court – and a breach of a Court order has more serious implications than a breach of an abatement notice (e.g. imprisonment for contempt of Court).
 
Generally, the Court will allow the person against whom an order is sought, to have the opportunity to present their side of the case, so the matter is not therefore entirely within the control of the council (as is the case with abatement notices). In some cases, interim enforcement orders will be granted ex parte (i.e. without the defendant/offender being heard) in which case an application to the Court to set the order aside will be necessary.

The most powerful enforcement tool for a council is their ability to prosecute, i.e. to pursue a criminal case alleging a breach of the RMA.
 
Unlike an appeal against an abatement notice or an application for an enforcement order (where the standard of proof is on the balance of probabilities), with prosecutions, the proof must be 'beyond reasonable doubt' (i.e. the prosecutor must be sure that the facts alleged are true).
 
Generally, prosecutions will be considered when an event or accident has occurred and has likely caused irreparable damage. For example, the cutting down of a significant native tree or the discharge of contaminants into a creek.  Prosecutions will often be pursued where there is an ongoing or frequent non-compliance.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for an example of a case where the Court sentenced an offender to imprisonment for on-going illegal earthworks and native bush clearance.
    R v Borrett [2004] NZRMA 248
     
    Mr and Mrs Borrett were charged for contravening an interim enforcement order and the rules of Waitakere City’s district plan.
     
    The Borretts had carried out illegal earthworks and native bush clearance on their property, which was situated in an area of special zoning under the plan (the zone had provisions designed to protect the native vegetation and natural landscape of the area).
     
    Mr Borrett had a history of contravening council requirements, having undertaken illegal earthworks and vegetation removal over a period of two years. The council applied for and obtained interim enforcement orders from the Environment Court.
     
    However, illegal earthworks continued on the property, and the Borretts were prosecuted  and were found guilty of breaching the district plan and the enforcement orders.
     
    A sentence of 12 weeks imprisonment was imposed upon Mr Borrett, whose involvement the Court found in the illegal works was of a greater extent than his wife, who was fined and ordered to pay costs totalling $12,500.
     
    Mr Borrett held the view that he was entitled to do what he liked upon his land, and that it did not impact on the wider environment. The Court’s reply to this was:
     
     '…The RMA recognises that the rights of a landowner are subject to broader public considerations. As to the wider environment, it can be destroyed by incremental activities such as those undertaken by Mr Borrett.'
     
    The Court felt it necessary that a significant penalty was imposed on Mr Borrett, given the seriousness of his breaching both the RMA and orders of the Environment Court.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
The penalties for the main offences under the RMA are significant:
 
  • criminal conviction
  • imprisonment of up to two years, or
  • a fine of up to $300,000 for an individual
  • a further fine for continuing offence of up to $10,000 per day
  • a fine of up to $600,000 for a company.

Page.Title: Who can commit an environment offence?

PageElement.TextBox:
The person who did the action can commit an environmental offence (eg the person who poured the substance down the drain or the person who drove the bulldozer and unlawfully cleared some native vegetation). This includes employees and contractors.  The person can be personally liable for an offence either separately, or in addition to, the organisation they work for.
 
A company can commit an offence through its employees and contractors (vicarious liability).
 
Managers and directors can be deemed personally liable for environmental offences committed by their organisations. Managers and directors can include chief executives or anyone concerned in the management of a company.
 
Public authorities, such as district and regional councils, government departments , and utility companies (e.g. water, energy, and port companies) are bound by the RMA and can also commit environmental offences.

Unlike some other criminal offences in which both a guilty intent and a wrongful act must be proved, there is no need to prove that a person intended to cause damage for offences under the RMA.
 
Any prosecution for a breach of the RMA is treated as a ‘strict liability offence’, which means there are limited defences available.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for strict liability offences
    In prosecutions for strict liability offences, it is not necessary to prove that a company or the person involved intended to commit the offence, or was reckless or negligent in the circumstances.
     
    The prosecution only has to show that the offence happened and that there is a link between the company or the employee or person. Strict liability offences are common under the RMA and require special care.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
However, it will be a defence to prove that the breach was:
 
  • necessary for the purposes of saving or protecting life or health, or
  • necessary to prevent serious damage to property or avoid an actual or likely adverse effect on the environment, or
  • beyond the control of the company/employee (for example, a natural disaster or sabotage).
 
In all these circumstances the company must be able to show that its actions were reasonable and that it took steps to mitigate or remedy any problems created by the breach.
 
In addition, if the company thinks the event in question was beyond its control, it must prove that the action or event could not reasonably have been foreseen. 
 
If the person or company intends to use any of these defences, they must notify the prosecutor of this, along with the supporting facts, within seven days of receiving the summons.  In other words, early action is essential.
 
This imposes a standard of care on companies to have an environmental management system in place which identifies the risks of an organisation’s operations and includes systems to prevent accidents happening in the first place.

Page.Title: Can an organisation be liable for environmental offences committed by someone else?

PageElement.TextBox:
An organisation or company can be legally responsible for environmental offences which are committed by its:
 
  • agents
  • contractors
  • employees.
 
This is called ‘vicarious liability’.
 
As a general rule, an organisation can be held responsible for the acts of contractors if it:
 
  • fails to take care in choosing an experienced and competent contractor
  • directly authorises the act to be done which constitutes the offence
  • exercises control and direction over the manner in which the work is carried out, which results in an offence. 
 
How to minimise the risk of vicarious liability

To minimise the risk of liability for an offence committed by an employee, an organisation should:
 
  • have an environmental management system which guides the conduct of managers and employees
  • have clear environmental checklists and procedures to follow so as to ensure employees are properly supervised
  • conduct training programs for employees so that they understand the company’s environmental policies and processes and which environmental laws apply to their work. 
 
To minimise the risk of liability for an offence committed by a contractor, an organisation should:
 
  • only engage qualified, competent and experienced contractors
  • address environmental risks in the contract: i.e. the contract should require the contractor to comply with the RMA and defined environmental procedures and standards
  • have an induction program to introduce the contractor to the site (the contract may require the contractor to induct its employees to the relevant environmental standards and procedures)
  • ensure that the contractor either complies with the organisation’s environmental management system, or has its own environmental management system in place
  • warn the contractor of any particular environmental risks associated with the work they have been asked to do
  • check the contractor’s work to ensure it complies with the relevant resource consents.

It is important to note that the company's directors and managers can potentially be liable for prosecution for a breach of the RMA.
 
This is the case even if she/he was not personally present when the offence took place.  Furthermore, environmental or public liability insurance is unlikely to provide full cover in this situation.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for Environmental Insurance Information
    Most companies in NZ still rely on their general public liability policy to cover any breach of the RMA. Those policies are limited, and are becoming more so. Any business at risk of liability under the RMA should consider specific environmental insurance. Even then, cover may only be available for accidental or unexpected events, and not for matters which should have been anticipated. Most are 'sudden event' type policies which do not deal with gradual environmental damage.
     
    Insurance against fines and penalties, and against legal costs incurred in defending prosecutions, may be of limited value. Such policies usually have a range of exclusions and there is debate as to whether they are enforceable at all as it is considered against public policy for a wrongdoer to be indemnified against criminal conduct, whether by an employer or an insurer.  Accordingly, no employee, whether management or otherwise, should rely on an insurance policy covering them for any such liabilities.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
To defend a prosecution requires establishment either that the director or manager had no knowledge of, or that all reasonable steps were taken to avoid, the commission of the offence. Hence it is essential to identify areas of environmental risk, and have proactive policies in place to avoid, mitigate or remedy that risk.
 
There have been relatively few prosecutions against managers or employees, but the threat of personal prosecution of company management still remains, especially in circumstances where they are aware of a breach occurring,  or where they are taking insufficient steps to avoid breaches occurring. In addition to the potential of a fine, there can be the additional liability for clean up costs which can be considerable. The prosecution process is also time consuming, expensive and can be inconvenient, stressful and distracting for those involved.

Environmental checklist:
 
  1. Air Discharges – Ensure that you either comply with the maximum discharge limits in the relevant regional planning instruments or apply to the regional council for a resource consent. If in doubt, contact the regional council’s planning desk for guidance.
 
  1. Stormwater – Discharge of natural rainwater to drains often requires a consent from the regional council depending on the area of impermeable surface at the site (e.g. including building footprint, hardstand, and parking areas). You will need to check the regional rules to establish whether a consent is required. This is particularly important where there are contaminants on the ground at the site, such as heavy metals, oils or grease.
 
  1. Wastewater – The regional council may also require a consent for discharge of wastewater/sewage into the reticulated system, depending on the rules in your region. This also needs to be checked.
 
  1. Trade Wastes – These are often governed by the bylaws of the local district council. You will need to check that you have a current ‘Trade Wastes’ agreement with the council which is in accordance with the permitted levels specified in the bylaws or the district plan.
 
  1. Hazardous Substances –  Storage, and dealing with hazardous substances on site, requires test certificates under the Hazardous Substances and New Organisms Act 1996. The administering body is the Environmental Risk Management Authority.
 
  1. On going compliance - Ensure that, once you have the necessary consents/permits in place, you have a regular monitoring and reporting program to ensure that the company complies with the terms of relevant approvals. Depending on the nature of your business, you could also consider preparing an Environmental Management Plan for sensitive sites, which would detail operational procedures to ensure that all stormwater, liquid wastes (including trade wastes), and solid wastes related to an activity, are treated, maintained, stored or disposed of in an appropriate way.

Is Mrs Brown able to take enforcement action against CFL Limited directly?
 
Yes, Mrs Brown can apply to the Court for an enforcement order to require the clean up of the site.
That is correct!
 
Enforcement orders can be applied for by any person regardless of whether the nuisance has been caused by the current land owner/occupier or a former owner. Abatement notices and infringement notices may only be issued by regional and district councils.
No, she will need to take the issue up with the local council. There is no direct action she is able to take.
That is incorrect.
